quizlist.question: What does the aesthetic-usability effect refer to?
quizlist.option1: People tend to perceive attractive products as more usable.
quizlist.option2: People tend to perceive usable products as more attractive.
quizlist.option3: Usability and aesthetics are equally important in web design.
quizlist.option4: The perception of attractiveness and usability of a new site are evaluated in the first 50ms when a user first sees the site.

quizlist.question: Which of the following is NOT a type of microcontent?
quizlist.source: Microcontent A Few Small Words Have a Mega Impact on Business

quizlist.question: Which of the following best describes the false-consensus effect?
quizlist.option1: People tend to assume that others share their beliefs and responses to a given situation.
quizlist.option2: Designers think that their favorite web-design patterns are more widespread than they are in reality.
quizlist.option3: People assume that their needs are unique most of the time, and that only in exceptional situations they will react in the same way as others.
quizlist.option4: Members of a team tend to act cohesively to give outsiders the illusion of consensus.
quizlist.source: You Are Not the User: The False-Consensus Effect

quizlist.question: What is a difference between a customer-journey map and an experience map?
quizlist.option1: The experience map is agnostic of any specific products, while the customer-journey map is tied to a specific product or service.
quizlist.option2: The customer-journey map depicts events in chronological order, but the experience map is not chronological or sequential.
quizlist.option3: The customer-journey map is focused on customers, while the experience map is focused on employees.
quizlist.option4: The customer-journey map offers a general human perspective, not specific to a particular user.
quizlist.source: UX Mapping Methods Compared: A Cheat Sheet

quizlist.question: Which of the following best describes the exhaustive-review eye-movement pattern?
quizlist.option1: The eyes are drawn to the same area of the page repeatedly because the UI violates user’s expectations.
quizlist.option2: The eyes are repeatedly drawn to the top left corner of the webpage because the user wants to make sure that the page belongs to the right site.
quizlist.option3: The eyes systematically visit all the areas of the page in an effort not to miss anything.
quizlist.option4: The eyes thoroughly scan the area of the page that has the most content.
quizlist.source: Exhaustive Review or I Can’t Believe It is Not There Phenomenon: Evidence from Eyetracking

quizlist.question: Which of the following does NOT usually appear in a service blueprint?
Which of the following is true of quantitative research?
quizlist.option1: It produces statistically meaningful results that are likely to be replicated in a different study.
quizlist.option2: It is used mostly for formative purposes, in the early stages of a design to inform design decisions.
quizlist.option4: It allows for flexible study conditions that can be adjusted from session to session according to the team’s needs.

quizlist.question: Which part of a webpage receives most of the users’ fixations?
quizlist.option3: Both sides of the page receive about an equal proportion of fixations.
quizlist.option4: It depends on the page level in the site’s IA hierarchy.

quizlist.question: What is one advantage of sliders for application design?
quizlist.option1: They allow users to explore the effect of the control for the whole range of the associated parameter.
quizlist.option2: They represent a more fun and engaging input method compared with other UI controls.
quizlist.option3: They support precise selection of a specific value within a range.
quizlist.option4: They allow both fine and coarse parameter adjustment.
quizlist.source: Input Controls for Parameters: Balancing Exploration and Precision with Sliders, Knobs, and Matrices

quizlist.question: Which of the following is true of tree testing?
quizlist.option1: It is devoid of any visual styling and does not reflect well the experience of interacting with the full design.
quizlist.option3: It should be done before card sorting when both card sorting and tree testing are used.
quizlist.option2: It does not typically collect any quantitative measures.
quizlist.option4: It can be used interchangeably with card sorting.
quizlist.source: Tree Testing Fast, Iterative Evaluation of Menu Labels and Categories and Tree Testing Part 2: Interpreting the Results
